advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Alice, a computer for all levels"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A selection for the Initiator... at Sinclair price</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PREVIOUS SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Before manufacturing the MPC, Columbia tried to sell a massive multi-user, Z80 based system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - HAPPY COUPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Part of a software advert<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issues of Byte Shopper</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from the Nieman-Marcus catalog.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> :-)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.cpu: Zilog Z80 - Optional Intel 8088 or Motorola 68008
computer.description:
An other CP/M / MSDOS hybrid system. This computer had no great commercial success.
The Decision Mate V came with 128 KB of RAM, but could be upgraded to 256 or 512 KB with expansion cards. The serial and Centronics interfaces were not on the mainboard, but were added as expansion cards. An additional card with a 68000 was developed by NCR in order to use CP/M 68.
There were 7 expansion slots. An optional diagnostic card was available for slot 6. Otherwise, diagnostics were produced through 6 red LEDs on the back of the case, above the volume control.
The computer had two floppy drives, or only one + a Winchester hard drive mounted in the second bay.
A network called 'DecisoNet' was designed to link together several Decision V.
_____________
Contributors: Sebastian Rho.
computer.keyboard: Typewriter type 91 keys with 20 programmable function keys and numeric keypad
computer.media: One or two floppy disk drives (320 KB each), 10 to 30 MB hard disk
computer.name: Decision Mate V
computer.ram: 64 kb, 128 kb, 256 kb or 512 kb depending of models (through expansion cards)
